JavaScript Ninja book - arguments.callee and bang bang construct

Jan 22, 2013

arguments.callee

arguments.callee - this property of a function can serve as a reliable way to always access the function itself.

var robot = { 
  dance: function(n) { 
    return n > 0 ? arguments.callee(n-1) + "eep" : "boop";
  }
}
// `arguments` points to the argument list passed into the function, in this case, `n`

!! operator

The !! construct is a way of turning any JavaScript expression into its Boolean equivalent

!!"hello" //outputs true

!!0 //outputs false
  • js
  • javascript
  • book
  • arguments

JavaScript Ninja notes - Anonymous and Inline functions

Jan 21, 2013

This in a method

A term frequently applied to functions that are referenced through object properties, the function context refers to teh boject through which the method was invoked. So given the following function, the assertions will evaluate to true:

var ninja = {
  // define object property with anonmyous function
  yell: function(n) {
    return n > 0 ? this.yell(n - 1) + 'a' : 'hiy';
  }
}

// make a reference to ninja method
var samurai = { yell: ninja.yell };

ninja = {};

try {
  assert(samurai.yell(4) == 'hiyaaaa', 'this works because of `this` var');
  }
catch(e) {
  console.log('if ninja.yell did not have this.yell in return, error would be thrown because reference would be gone');
}

Given the same object without reference to this, the assertion will fail

var ninja = {
  // define object property with anonmyous function, but no `this` reference
  yell: function(n) {
    return n > 0 ? yell(n - 1) + 'a' : 'hiy';
  }
}

// make a reference to ninja method
var samurai = { yell: ninja.yell };

ninja = {};

try {
  assert(samurai.yell(4) == 'hiyaaaa', 'this doesnt work because we kill reference to ninja.yell');
  }
catch(e) {
  console.log('if ninja.yell did not have this.yell in return, error would be thrown because reference would be gone');
}

Named anonymous (inline) functions

Function literal syntax allows us to supply a name to the declared function by adding a name before the parameter list. Another name for this is an inline function.

Note: inline functions can be named, but those names are only visible within the functions themselves

var ninja = {
  // `shout` is an inline function
  yell: function shout(n) {
    return n > 0 ? shout(n-1) + 'a' : 'hiy';
  }
}

var samurai = { yell: ninja.yell };
ninja = {};

assert(samurai.yell(4) == 'hiyaaaa', 'Yes, this method still works because we save reference directly to the inline function that is named `shout`');

assert(typeof shout == "undefined", 'true since can not evaluate inline function outside of its scope directly');
  • js
  • javascript
  • book
  • notes
  • inline
  • functions
  • anonymous

Webstorm node.js debug configuration

Jan 20, 2013

Some WebStorm IDE configuration settings so that I can debug a node.js application. I didn’t need to do anything special with MongoDB. Just had to make sure $mongod was running before I set WebStorm to run.

node.js app debug config

node.js remote debug config

After clicking on run, set a breakpoint in your node.js app and click on the debug button. You should be good to go and step into code, expecting vars and what not.

WebStorm IDE and Debugging Node.js app

Jan 17, 2013

I’m evaluating WebStorm JavaScript IDE and I have to say it was super easy to setup and use. I’m working on a command-line app to create and manage todo lists and the usual suspects for debugging node.js like node-inspector was just clunky to set up.

Below is a screenshot that shows how I used the WebStorm debugger on my mocha tests. Suhweeet.

Note: Just follow this tutorial to set up the debugger with your node and mocha libraries: Debugging Mocha unit tests with WebStorm step-by-step

Refactoring to Patterns book notes

Jan 17, 2013

TDD methodology help with the following

  • keep defect counts low
  • refactor without fear
  • produce simpler, better code
  • program without stress

Motivation for refactoring

  • to reduce or remove duplication
  • to simplify what is complicated
  • to make code better at communicating its intention
